channel.title: Microsoft vs Google vs Apple
channel.description:
Many of you skiddies don't know this but once Microsoft got on top of the world they realized they wouldn't be in that position forever and decided to invest a large cash stack into other companies such as apple, best buy, facebook etc etc.
So I would first like to point out that Microsoft is already a winner. They gave up the throne willingly and now Google is the top dog. Apple finally was in a position to take over the world but lost that vision when Steve Jobs passed away. In recent news Apple is fading away with their 120 billion dollars in the bank, failing to reinvest it into other companies or utilize it to take on their competition.
Google is soaring and has proved their dominance in every aspect of the market: Advertising, Books, Music, Superior Search Engine, Maps, Android OS etc etc.
With the information you know about these companies from your own beliefs, experience or what you have heard...
Which company do you favor? If you can give advice to any of the three companies on what they should do next, what advice would you give them? Do you think Facebook or Yahoo even have a chance?

item.title: Microsoft vs Google vs Apple
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“Rodgerwilco, post:3, topic:519377”][quote author=drubrkletern link=topic=637839.msg4299127#msg4299127 date=1368687396]
Death to apple
Praise MS
[/quote]

Why death to apple? If they get their shit together they can be superior. They have 120 billion in the bank yet fail to put it to use. They have the potential to take on google and microsoft (as they have already proven). Really… does one guy make all the difference? Apple is very limited because of their failure to adapt. They will be ran over like they never existed unless the reach outside the box.[/quote]It’s not always about the money. They’re all about ripping off their customers while they have ZERO clue about it. Hell, a whole new market opened up because of Apple. Yano, that one where rich people trade in their old phones so they can buy the brand new one? (knowing that 5-6 months prior, they released yet another under the market product, but still claimed to be pioneers) They don’t build any of their devices to last. They’re always one step behind the market, but for some reason they were able to put together so many fuckin’ fanboys that they can keep making commercials.

Read full topic

item.title: Microsoft vs Google vs Apple
item.dc:creator: @Mitko Mitko
item.description:
@Mitko wrote:

I personally favor Google for all of their useful products. They may not have Microsoft’s widely used OS for computers, or Apple’s well known high quality products, but they seem to slowly be dominating.

They bought Android and have improved it so much that most manufacturers now use it for their tablets, phones, there are even now smartwatches. They made something magnific such as Street view which is something that someone like myself could have never imagined to see on a computer. Oh, and let’s not forget the world’s most popular search engine, YouTube, Adsense, Gmail and the list goes on…

Read full topic

item.title: Microsoft vs Google vs Apple
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

[quote=“Rodgerwilco, post:39, topic:519377”][quote author=The Web Guy link=topic=637839.msg4303580#msg4303580 date=1369406049]
Google with their Android operating systems, dominate the mobile operating systems. And are very customize-able for mobile devices.

As for operating systems, Microsoft wins.
For mobile devices, Apple wins. (iPad, iPods, etc.)
[/quote]

Obviously they are not dominate if iOS has more users. Don’t contradict yourself and provide facts please.

The other day I saw a bunch of mac fags buy a computer for $1400 that I could of bought for $600 and installed iOS on it…[/quote]

I’m not contradicting myself. Mobile devices, and mobile operating systems are two completely different things, am I right? Apple does a great job when it comes to the hardware of iPads, iPhones, iPods, etc.

However, there’s no doubt that Android is dominate when it comes to the operating system. iOS isn’t too good, too simple.

On topic:

I think we all can come to a mutual agreement that Apple beats Microsoft and Google when it comes to using the same letter in every device/software name. Lmao

Read full topic

item.title: Microsoft vs Google vs Apple
item.dc:creator: @Kidpaparoach Kidpaparoach
item.description:
@Kidpaparoach wrote:

[quote=“Niall, post:90, topic:519377”][quote author=Kidpaparoach link=topic=637839.msg4314043#msg4314043 date=1371163939]
The Ps3 was overpriced too. Many things Sony release are overpriced but they caters to all markets so that is to be expected. As a whole, I like Sony; they release good quality products.
[/quote]

The PS3 wasn’t overpriced when you look at it on paper though. Sure, the PS3 was ridiculously expensive at launch, so much so that Sony sold the PS3 at a loss for quite some time. But for that initial £425 price tag, you got the cheapest Bluray player, you got a removable hard-drive, you could play PS2 games, you had built in wifi, and you had HDMI from launch. The launch Xbox’s didn’t have HDMI until 2007 (conveniently when the PS3 was released, WITH HDMI), launch Xbox’s had no wifi (with the official dongle being $100), and depending on the model the launch Xbox’s didn’t have a harddrive, at £209 and £279 respectively.

The PS3 dropped the price to £399 quickly after launch, and 8 months later in November 2007 Sony released the 40gb PS3 at £299. In August 2007 Microsoft had came out with the Xbox Elite, which I believe finally had wifi, being priced at oh, look at that, £299.

So sure, the PS3 may have been overpriced at launch compared to launch 360 models, but the 360 models were gimped and when they finally weren’t gimped they came out competitively priced with each other. I feel it’s a cheap tactic, but there’s a reason the 360 launch models were so cheap, a reported 34% failure rate.[/quote]
Wut. Well they attempted to add in far too much then. It is well known one of the reasons why the PS3 wasn’t as successful as the Xbox 360 is because of it’s price tag aka the ps3 was overpriced; I’m not talking about the value ratio as that’s subjective + I cba.

Read full topic

item.title: Microsoft vs Google vs Apple
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

Google is at the top, and is only going to get further. With them dominating everything, think about it. Google has done so much. Google+ (which wasn’t too successful), Google Chrome (most used web browser), Android Operating Systems, Google Tools, Google Maps, and no one will ever forget the Google Search Engine. There really is no competing with Google. I mean, shit, they have been working on self-driven cars.

Read full topic

item.title: Microsoft vs Google vs Apple
item.dc:creator: @The_Un-Named The Un-Named
item.description:
@The_Un-Named wrote:

Kidpaparoach:

The Ps3 was overpriced too. Many things Sony release are overpriced but they caters to all markets so that is to be expected. As a whole, I like Sony; they release good quality products.

The PS3 wasn’t overpriced when you look at it on paper though. Sure, the PS3 was ridiculously expensive at launch, so much so that Sony sold the PS3 at a loss for quite some time. But for that initial £425 price tag, you got the cheapest Bluray player, you got a removable hard-drive, you could play PS2 games, you had built in wifi, and you had HDMI from launch. The launch Xbox’s didn’t have HDMI until 2007 (conveniently when the PS3 was released, WITH HDMI), launch Xbox’s had no wifi (with the official dongle being $100), and depending on the model the launch Xbox’s didn’t have a harddrive, at £209 and £279 respectively.

The PS3 dropped the price to £399 quickly after launch, and 8 months later in November 2007 Sony released the 40gb PS3 at £299. In August 2007 Microsoft had came out with the Xbox Elite, which I believe finally had wifi, being priced at oh, look at that, £299.

So sure, the PS3 may have been overpriced at launch compared to launch 360 models, but the 360 models were gimped and when they finally weren’t gimped they came out competitively priced with each other. I feel it’s a cheap tactic, but there’s a reason the 360 launch models were so cheap, a reported 34% failure rate.

Read full topic
